results.title: Watch the Gap
results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Campbell Manderson and Pip Starr
results.brief_description: A sometimes-humorous report on Pine Gap and its strategic use against US military enemies. It also examines the efforts of the Nuclear Disarmament Party to uncover what exactly Pine Gap is being used for. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Campbell Manderson and Pip Starr
results.brief_description: A look at the negative effects of corporate globalization has on the environment and human rights laws. Screened as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Fire, Water, Earth
results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Campbell Manderson and Pip Starr
results.brief_description: A report on the environmental damage that the Western Mining Corporation is causing to the Arabunna people by the siphoning of 42 million litres of water a day from the Great Artesian Basin. The world’s largest uranium mine is located at Roxby Downs in South Australia. It is owned by multinational mining corporation WMC and is built on Arabunna and Kokotha land. This story follows the nuclear trail from an occupation of a WMC borefield by Arabunna elder Kevin Buzzacott and his supporters to a daring mission by videoactivists into the heart of WMC headquarters in Melbourne, surprising the boss himself.Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: World Class De-Forestation
results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Campbell Manderson and Pip Starr
results.brief_description: A look at the damaging effects of the de-forestation occurring in the East Gippsland forest ranges and the efforts of a group of activists to stop it. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Top shelf
results.brief_description: This stylish short animation borrows from the tradition of nastier fairytales. This creepy cautionary fable outlines what can happen to little girls who whine for toys.

group_siblings.title: Telestreet: the Italian Media Jacking Movement

results.title: Telestreet: the Italian Media Jacking Movement
results.brief_description: “Telestreet” is a network of pirate micro TV transmitters set up by media activists across Italy. Since beginning in June 2002 there are now almost 200 stations throughout the country. This documentary contains interviews with some of those media activists.
results.description: “Telestreet” is a network of pirate micro TV transmitters set up by media activists across Italy. Since beginning in June 2002 there are now almost 200 stations throughout the country. This documentary contains interviews with some of those media activists.

results.title: Mary
results.brief_description: ‘Mary’ combines colour film from the early 1950s as well as modern 16mm footage. Scratched and painted upon, this experimental film links timeless images of the ocean with old footage of a young woman. The effect is both mysterious and moody creating an intangible, lingering feeling of melancholy.

results.title: Heaps good: Muph n Plutonic
results.brief_description: This music video featuring animation was made by Melbourne-based video artist and animator, Anto Skene. ‘Heaps Good’ is a track from the first collaboration of acclaimed Melbourne hip hop artist MC Muphin and one of Australia’s highest profile producers, Plutonic Lab. Quality local production featuring hot local sounds.

results.title: Dog gone
results.brief_description:
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2004.
Sal completed Dog Gone as a student at AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT. Utilising two different animation techniques (clay and hand drawn), this work is a short fantasy tale about an old dog who runs away from home to learn a few new tricks.
